pullRequest.body:
Disprove the Aharoni–Korman conjecture by constructing and verifying Hollom's counterexample. Additionally show this counterexample is countable and scattered.

Zulip thread: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Aharoni.E2.80.93Korman.20conjecture.20formally.20disproved

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.



-->

- [x] depends on: #20752
- [x] depends on: #20753 
- [x] depends on: #20754

By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I propose merging this in a couple of days on the following basis: several of us looked at the statement of the theorem proved here, and compared it with the statement of the theorem in the ArXiv paper, and agreed that indeed this is a correct formalization of the counterexample. The file is however a bit slow and we did not really look at the actual code, on the basis that code in Counterexamples is usually not held to such high standards as code in Mathlib.
What a beautiful achievement in near-real-time formalization!
`apply_eq_of_line_eq_step` also seems a little slow. Maybe avoiding `Fintype` and using `Finite` can help?

I am aware that this suggestion is more likely to make you think "wow, that Mitchell sure is an insufferable pedant" than "thanks, Mitchell!". I hope you can forgive me.
```suggestion
# Disproof of the Aharoni–Korman conjecture
```
nit: parens here are a lean3ism
Should we have `def AharoniKorman : Prop :=` to make this clearer?
I'm not really sure I see the benefit, but also there's not much harm. It is really that much cleaner to abstract out the contents of the `¬`?

```suggestion
  toFun : α → α
  mem' : ∀ x, toFun x ∈ C
  eq_self_of_mem' : ∀ x ∈ C, toFun x = x
  fibre_antichain' : ∀ x, IsAntichain (· ≤ ·) (toFun ⁻¹' {x})
```
This is quite slow (profiling said it took 6 seconds and it's not immediately clear what is costing so much). Is there any chance of speeding it up?

There's not really much going on in this, it's just easy calls to omega and the equation compiler checking I've covered all the cases. As far as I can tell, the only speedups would be to improve one of those two, which I'm not good enough to do!
What happens replacing all the `omega` by `sorry`?

Then it takes under a second, but note that making them sorry turns off the final step (which looks like the slowest) of the kernel checking that the elaborated term is type correct. I can try to replace them all by explicit proofs, ~~but I expect this won't be faster.~~ edit: I changed my mind about the last bit.
Oh. For me, linting this single instance takes 12 seconds.
Printing out more detail from the profiler tells me that each omega call takes less 100ms, and the majority of them take less than 10ms. So I don't think omega is the culprit here.
The unused variables linter is taking almost all of the 12 seconds for me. It also didn't spot the unused variable in the `le_refl` part...

Proving
```lean
lemma HollomOrder.trans (x y z : Hollom) (h₁ : HollomOrder x y) (h₂ : HollomOrder y z) :
    HollomOrder x z :=
  match x, y, z, h₁, h₂ with
  | _, _, _, .twice _, .twice _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .twice _, .within _ _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .twice _, .next_min _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .twice _, .next_add _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .within _ _, .twice _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .within _ _, .within _ _ => .within (by omega) (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .within _ _, .next_min _ => .next_min (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .within _ _, .next_add _ => .next_add (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_min _, .twice _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_min _, .within _ _ => .next_min (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_min _, .next_min _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_min _, .next_add _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_add _, .twice _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_add _, .within _ _ => .next_add (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_add _, .next_min _ => .twice (by omega)
  | _, _, _, .next_add _, .next_add _ => .twice (by omega)
```
before defining the instance seems much faster on my computer.
Yes, but `antisymm` is the problem here, I believe this just shifts the problem to the proof of antisymm being really slow.
Oh, I misunderstood you, that's also way faster for me! Very strange...
Are you sure? I am going to dinner so I don't have time to check, but extracting transitivity seems to make the yellow bar really faster.
I have made this change, thanks!
I think our messages crossed each other. You're absolutely correct, and I've amended.
@kbuzzard are you happy with the new version?
Why not subscripts? Lean allows `₁` and `ₕ` in identifiers.
I think the subscript l is hard to read and looks too much like a 1. But I'm reasonably happy either way - maybe this one should just be private!
LMAO, I mistook `l` for `1` already as it is.
In general, I am a fan of private lemmas, but I am clearly a minority here.
How do you feel about making this a one-field structure? I suspect that could be the cause of the performance issues. I can push a fix if you like.

I find it hard to believe that is the cause, but if it is then go right ahead! I believe I avoided defeq abuse pretty consistently, except for perhaps in the first ~150 lines, so hopefully this isn't too tricky to do.
Pushed the commit, but it wasn't the cause of the `trans` slowness
The congr 3 <;> omega is a nice spot though!
(If you feel strongly, perhaps revert the structure changes but keep the lemmas added to avoid defeq abuse?)
No strong feeling, I'm happy with this.
I really don't understand what is going on here, but could it have 3 fields instead?

```lean
structure Foo where
  bar : Nat
```
defines a structure given by one field (a natural number), so if you have `N : Foo` then `N.bar` is a number. Here `Hollom` is given by a triple of natural numbers. In the other direction, if you have a natural number `n` you can of course build a term of type `Foo`, and the constructor is called `Foo.mk` by defaul. In the `Hollom` example it would be called `Hollom.mk`, and the syntax `toHollom ::` just changes the name to `Hollom.toHollom`.
Three fields would probably be more work, because then you have no `Prod` lemmas available.

```suggestion
Copyright (c) 2025 Bhavik Mehta. All rights reserved.
```
Bhavik claimed copyright last year (this PR is from december), so I think it was correct as is.

```suggestion
variable {n : ℕ}

lemma R_subset_level : R n C ⊆ level n := Set.sep_subset (level n) _
```
nit: consider adding to `references.bib`

pullRequest.title: feat(Counterexamples): disproof of the Aharoni–Korman conjecture

Is this ready for review? I guess not, as there is a section marked "to_move", and it's way over the usual length limit for a single PR; but it's appearing in the review queue.

If my guess is correct, could you please mark it as WIP?

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Set/Finite): a set is finite if its image and fibers are finite
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/WellFoundedSet): add convenience constructors for IsWF and IsPWO for WellFoundedLT types
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Data/Finset/Card): add `InjOn` and `SurjOn` versions of finset cardinality lemmas
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Set/Function): prove surjectivity from composition
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Order): relate chains to antichains
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/Chain): adapt linear order lemmas to chains
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/Chain): condition for the union of chains to be a chain
[Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/Interval/Finset): map sectL and sectR on finset intervals
